Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of an SEM-EDS System: Advancing Scientific Discovery and Student Scientific Inquiry in Rural Illinois
Award.AbstractNarration:
Western Illinois University will acquire a Scanning Electron Microscope with an Energy-Dispersive detector for research and undergraduate education in the Departments of Geology, Chemistry, Biological Sciences, and Anthropology. Research ranges from basic study of non-biologic materials to organisms that require high magnification to observe. The electron microscope system will also be integrated in the training of undergraduate and graduate students who are part of Western Illinois' Research Inspiring Student (RISE) program, giving them important experience with state-of-the-art observational and analytical tools. The electron microscope system will be used as well in a cooperative outreach program to help bring meaningful scientific experiences to primary and secondary classrooms in rural Illinois.

This project will enable Western Illinois University (WIU) to acquire an SEM (Scanning Electron Microscope) with EDS (energy dispersive X-ray), The availability of this equipment will help advance active research programs at a small rural institution in western Illinois that range from the basic study of inorganic materials to complex symbiotic associations between plants and microorganisms. The specific research projects include studying 1) factors and processes involved in decay and preservation of vertebrates, 2) synthesis, structure, and properties of inorganic materials, 3) evolution of clam shrimp and the processes involved in fossil preservation, 4) deep processes involved in magmatic mixing events, 5) feeding morphology in invertebrates, 6) microbial involvement in the unique rock formations found within caves, and 7) plant-fungal interactions and microbial adaptations to extreme conditions. Students, both from the sciences and science education, will be exposed to this modern equipment in their classes and through individual research projects as part of the opportunities offered by the Research Inspiring Student (RISE) program at WIU.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF award titled “MRI: Acquisition of an SEM-EDS System: Advancing Scientific Discovery and Student Scientific Inquiry in Rural Illinois,” has had a significant impact on Western Illinois University and surrounding region. Looking at the Western Illinois University several faculty from Biology, Chemistry, Geology, and Physics have integrated the instrument into their research programs. As a direct result of this integration numerous undergraduate and graduate students have had direct hands-on experience with the instrument. This has provided them with on the job training required to be successful in their next steps. While not every student goes on to use a Scanning Electron Microscope in their future endeavors, the training provided by using modern technology cannot be overlooked. A new course has been developed to allow students, both graduate and undergraduate, an in-depth experience with the instrument outside of a research setting. The region has also benefitted from the acquisition of the instrument, particular K-12 students. The instrument has been incorporated into two WIU sponsored summer camps where the campers examined everyday objects in ways they have never done before. A local boy scout troop spent an evening with the instrument looking at different organisms and geological samples. The instrument has been used the past few years as a part of the Girl Scouts Day on campus. Finally, local students have come to WIU during open house days, recruiting days, and students who visit WIU have had the chance to see the scanning electron microscope and what the instrument can do. Western Illinois University is grateful to the National Science Foundation Major Research Instrumentation Program for providing the funding to acquire the instrument.
